title: Shiori Miyagi and Maximum Array Score
statementHtml:
For the cost of 5000 yen, Miyagi can ask Sendai to do whatever she wants! Today, Miyagi demands that Sendai make her an array... specifically, Miyagi only wants a very particular type of array.

For arbitrary integers b≥2b≥2 and x≥1x≥1, define v(b,x)v(b,x) to be the maximal kk satisfying bk∣xbk∣x; that is, the maximal kk such that xx is a multiple of bkbk. It can be shown that this is always a well-defined, nonnegative integer.

You are given integers nn and mm satisfying n≤mn≤m. Find the maximum value of ∑ni=2v(i,ai)∑i=2nv(i,ai) across all arrays aa of length nn satisfying the following conditions:
inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (2≤n≤m≤2⋅1052≤n≤m≤2⋅105).

It is guaranteed that the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer, the maximum value of ∑ni=2v(i,ai)∑i=2nv(i,ai) across all arrays aa of length nn satisfying the given conditions.
noteHtml:
In the first example, one possible array is a=[6,8,9,16]a=[6,8,9,16] which yields a value of 3+2+2=73+2+2=7.

It can be shown that this is the maximum value of ∑ni=2v(i,ai)∑i=2nv(i,ai) across all arrays aa of length nn satisfying the given conditions.
